title: Addressing legislative specifics on the national level – example of Slovenia

author: Nataša Pirc Musar, Information Commissioner of the Republic of Slovenia, Government of the Republic of Slovenia

segmentation: No.
Mr Bush appears musar.
Mr Currently working as Information Commissioner Lou Public of Slovenia.
She's a lawyer education and has extensive experience in journalism.
And she started working in 204.
Us as the.
Public information and then the position joint into the Information Commissioner position, which he calls now.
She will be.
She's been elected just recently for the next time.
Five year term.
And then she will be talking about the legislative specifics of national level legislation in Slovenia.
First of all, thank you for inviting me and I do apologize for being late, but I had urgent things to do regarding the H1N1 contract with Glaxo, Smith Kline and Slovenian Health Ministry.

I don't know whether you are aware, but around Europe and around the world are now a lot of requests for revealing those kind of documents contracts among the governments and pharmaceutical companies.
Slovenia is no exception.
Regarding this, the Ministry of Health is trying to hide the contract.

But media and public is expecting me to decide whether this contract should be secret or not, and I already set a couple of weeks ago that the whole contract cannot be a secret document by no means by according to Slovenian law.
So this is what I've been doing for the last couple of weeks.
And today the media is just asking me when my decision is going to be issued and it's going to be tomorrow.
So quite a lot for me to do.
My colleague already explained you that under the roof of the Information Commissioner we are dealing with two basic human rights.
One is access to public information and the and the other one is personal data protection.
Regarding health documents, we do have a lot to do in our country.
I don't know whether you know, but Slovenia was one of the countries which adopted actually quite late.
The patients act.
It was enacted in August 2008, so it's it was put into force abit more than a year ago and it's new.
Into our legal system's legal system, and I have to say that.
Even the practitioners the doctors are not completely aware of everything what this law actually gives to the patient.
There is a lot of reluctance on their side, and I'm putting a lot of effort and forced to to learn them to teach them about the law.
And I have to tell you that they do listen.
They are aware that they have to cope with it, and I I hope that's doing is going to catch up with the with the countries with the States who are more developed in in in this field.
Briefly, I will talk about what actually this patient and patient act is bringing to our legal system.
But for the beginning, do you maybe know what?
Is this picture all about?
Do you recognize?
The photo.
What did you say?
You don't know it's their own bathroom.
The Roman ruins in one of the most beautiful cities remains of the Roman cities in the world.
It's called Leptis Magna in Libya.
If you haven't been there, I strongly recommended, but this is a Roman bathroom and people used to sit, you know, like 30 people all together in one stone bench and they were doing the business.
You know, talking to each other and underneath the water was flowing and it was taken away.
All the things that we were throwing out of our bodies, yeah, what do I want to say with this photo?
Can you imagine doing?
Business in the bathroom.
Like this today?
Would be accepted.
To see it also they had hours for ladies and hours for men.
That's what they did, yeah, so they were polite enough not to merge them, you know?
With this photo, I just want to say that privacy is rapidly changing through time.
This was many many years ago.
600 years ago.
And today, even when I go to the ladies room and there are no complete walls, you know there is a hole underneath and above me.
I still have problems.
Where can I do my business?
I mean, am I too loud so I feel you know not completely.
Relaxed proper word.
Regarding data protection and information technologies, we have to be aware that today information technologies offer.
Everything, everything is on the market and we can buy it.

Actually some of some of the software quite cheaply, but I often say that as the Information Commissioner we have to be aware that despite having all the information technologies available, we have to be aware that regarding human rights we are not allowed to use them in an open manner without any limits.
In health system.
We have the same problems as in in, in in in other system where they have a lot of data filing systems.
I collect sketches, cartoons.
This is one of my favorite waste of free time and the first one here is like the patient is entering the waiting room and and an assistant oh hemorrhoids aisle.
6 room number 5 is everybody can hear and we had a problem in Slovenia.
One of the patients appeals to my body and he said that.
Medical nurse loudly said Mr John Smith vasectomy room 605 everybody was looking at this man over Sectomy Carbodies kid doing so with those sketches without with those cartoons.
I just wanted to express how carefully we have to deal with personal data within the health system.
The other one is just, you know, the doctors are talking to the patient and then the cleaning lady is just, you know.
Listening what they have to say about this is actually that it's an exaggeration.
It's not happening in the practice, but it's just.
Another factor of that we have to think, thinking, thinking.
The sketch here on your left side was drawn when we had a lot of problems with our oncological Institute who was not properly taken care of all the medical health data of their patients.

They were just stored in open closets where all the patients who were walking by they were able to take the documents out and this is like, you know a cartoon explaining that the people are not bored in the waiting room anymore because they are able to read the documentation of other patients.
Yeah.
And I was very strict on the oncological Institute.
I issued a penalty because they were not storing the data properly and now the things are rapidly changing at the oncological Institute as well.
The other cartoon is about Middle Ages.
You were when the plague was one of the most deadly diseases and the houses where the patients.
Where which had a plague, they just put a cross on on on on on the door.

If today we would do something with the HI HIV virus or we put a sign on the door where those kind of people leave that would be you know outrageous yeah so this is another example how the right of privacy is rapidly changing through time.
I will just briefly go through the patients Act.
I don't know how much you do know the personal data protection in European Union, but Slovenia is not an exception.
We have to follow the Directive 9546 which has very strict rules regarding data protection principles, especially data security.
And according to Slovenian legal system.
Are only two basic principles of law for personal data processing.

One is if you if it's so provided by law and the other legal bases the individual individuals consent when we're talking about the public sector, our allotted data protection law strictly prohibits individuals consent, so there has to be a provision in the law in accordance to process the personal data.
The health system is not an exception.

So in that case, when we do have a provision in the law, the patient on the other side doesn't have a discretion to say I don't want to give you this personal data and the medical institution on the other side cannot say.
Oh OK, if you don't want to give it to us, we will not take it.
They have to have it in the filing system and the patient on the other side has to give it to the data controller.
One new data filing system was introduced to the Slovenian Patients Act and this is waiting list data finding system.
I don't know how is this in in other Democratic countries, but in Slovenia there is a lot of corruption.
Petty corruption, I don't know if they if the doctors are accepting a lot of money, maybe a sausage sausage is sometimes enough for a Cup of coffee.
I don't know, but if you do know a doctor you can you know?
Get a service faster.
The patients act.
Is trying to.
Get rid of those minuses if I may say so.
And waiting waiting lists are now a necessity.
All the medical institutions have to have them.
They still don't.

Year after the law was enacted, so we're actually quite slow in implementing this provision, but this is a new data filing system and the lies saying that everybody who's on the list has a right to see.
Whether he is moving up and down on this list properly and according to the law.
But we have to be care of the personal data.
Here again, yeah, the patient who is.
Look into this filing system does not have a right to see the name and a second name of the patient who's on the list.
That's why we put in the law that the waiting list should be carried out with so called health insurance number.

Every person in Slovenia has a so called health insurance number, which is a so called unique identifiable number and only according to this number the patients can check whether somebody was passing him in a proper manner or.
Not according to the law.
Another important aspect of the waiting list is.
That data controllers have to be careful when they exchange the personal data through the electronic means and Data Protection Act.
In Slovenia requires crypto crypto, public cryptography and electronic signatures, so all the data controllers.
To have if they want to exchange the data electronically, the electronic signature in crypto methods implemented into the system.
Public health Institute of the Republic of Slovenia is in charge of having a so called Central Register of the waiting list.

They are connected electronically to the central registry of the whole population of Slovenia and they have to inform the medical institution whether some but some patients already died and he's on a waiting list.
Unfortunately, so that the medical institution can remove the name from the waiting list.
The Health Institute is also in charge to check whether one patient is on two or three or maybe even on.
For waiting list for the same operation, then they have to inform the patient to say you have to decide which institution is going to be your priority.
If you're not going to decide, we will remove you from all the waiting list, but we leave you only on one waiting list, so this is the way we're trying to push the medical system to work proper.
The same rules apply for all the data filing systems within the Health Institute within the health system.
Examination of the data is provided by the law and the medical provider has to give a chance and has to give.
Time and a proper date to the patients to see what kind of data the medical institution is holding on on his behalf.

If the medical institution is denying the access to a patient, then there is a possibility to appeal in front of the Information Commissioner, so Information Commissioner Commissioner is a so called second instance body.
The appeal body.
I'm always explaining how the medical institutions have to be careful when giving the information via telephone.
Medical personal data is a so-called sensitive personal data.
If the medical institution is not sure whether the right person is on the other side claiming to check the medical data of.
Her or himself, or if there is a relative who has a legal right to check the medical data of a patient who is in the hospital.
They have to be very careful.
Slovenia is a small country.

We have hospitals around the country which cover the not so huge population in a lot of cases medical staff do know the people who are claiming the data in our home and set off and say if you are sure that there is the right person on the other side then give the information via telephone.
But if you are not sure don't do it.
Then invite the person to the hospital, check the identity the medical staff has a right to see the ID card they they.
They have the right to check whether the right person is in front of them or not.
The patients rights to information is part of the Slovenian Constitution as well the rights to oversee your own personal data is part of the human rights of data protection principles.
The medical institution has to decide in five days and as I said already, then the person has rights to appeal to the Information Commissioner.
But I have to stress the Information Commissioner does not have the power to correct the data in the data filing system if the person is not satisfied with the diagnosis.
I cannot say that this diagnosis is the right order.
Wrong one, I can only decide whether the patient has a right to seed and small corrections is something.
For example, the date of birth is not correct.
If the second name is misspelled wrongly and things like that.
Another one more important, app aspects of the Patients Act was introduced.
It was enacted the right.
To oversee the personal data to decide whether I want to have an operation or not, the age was lowered from 18 to 15.
So according to our law, the people who are.
At the age 15 and war have total rights to decide whatever they want to do with their bodies, and they have the rights to decide who can see their own personal data or not.
As the Information Commissioner, I had a lot of problems about the costs of giving the information to patients.
Alot of health institutions were charging enormous amounts of money for one photocopy it exactly.

I had a case when a private medical office was charging 10 euros per page for a photocopy of a medical documentation and I got really very mad because we are talking about a human right about the right of the person to see the data and I went to the Ministry of Justice and I asked them to enact.
A regulation who will regulate the costs of photo copies and now all the institution, no matter the public or private.
They can only charge $0.10 per photocopy.
So this is very, very important.
Why am I talking actually about photocopies in our system and I think it's pretty basically in the same around European Union.
The ownership of the documentation concept is that the patient is not the owner of the dock of the original documentation.
The data controller is the owner of all the original documents.
That's why they have to be very careful when when passing the documentation to other doctor to other institution.
According to our law, they only they are only allowed to give a photocopy per patient, but the original documentation has to travel in original form from the data controller to a data controller.
We had a case in Slovenia when one patient who had a.
Was mentally ill and and the doctor gave the documentation of these patients to his hands and he was he burned all the documentation.
So he's all history.
Medical history was destroyed.
That's why I'm saying that the data controller is in charge of the original documentation and they have to be very careful when they are, you know.
Passing the documentation from one data controller to an.
Who is actually authorized to access our medical data in the course of our life?
So when we are still alive, our data.
Our patients act is giving the chance to a patient that he decides who beside him can see the data of his or her own matters and our law.
2 minutes more.
So I have to speed up.
You see when I start talking then.
I'll speed up, I don't, but I will not go through all the slides.
So basically there are two rules.
If the patient does not decide who can see the patients data, then the law is giving strictly like numerous clausus facts who can actually see the data in who can then basically not see the data.
So family members like spouse, cohabiting, partner, civil union partners.
Which means homosexual partners, adoptive parents, grandparents and so on.
That's why I'm always saying to health institutions that.
They.
Are obliged to give a patient a chance to inform the patient that it's his decision who is going to allow whom is he going to allow?
See the medical dates are not if he's not deciding if he's unconscious when he enters the medical institution, then of course the legal provisions come into force.
I will just mention one more article which is very, very interesting.
Actually quite demanding for medical doctors.
The medical doctors have an obligation to inform third people about the disease of a patient that they treat when they think that the patient's condition can influence the life of a third person.
This is actually for medical doctors quite hard to decide.
For example, if we are talking about the HIV virus and the patient is going to say OK, I'm going to have sex with my wife, but I'm not going to tell her that I have HIV is.
Andy's obligation to tell the wife.
Clearly we can say yes, it's easy to tell the wife, yeah, but.
All the moral obligations that the doctors have are not so easy to do.
Decided and I often say 2 two MD's when they're saying, oh, this law is only giving the rights to the patients the lies, not talking about the obligations of the patients.
It's not telling us what kind of.
Maneuvering space the doctors have.
And I always say I don't envy you that you have to.
Receive decisions like this, but for us lawyers, it's easy to write the law.
But when when we have to use it in practice, it brings a lot of complications, but the lawyers are here again.
Took out the doctors.
We do have also special system for receiving the data when the patient unforced.
Unfortunately dies, then the law is also again saying who is allowed.
Not.
Another important aspect is Despite that.

Decision of the patient when he was still alive when he said that only this and these people are allowed to see the data the law is giving the opportunity after the debt that some people still have the right according to the law to see the data and the medical profession said that this is for genetical purposes.

So the doctor had two doctors has to have to decide whether certain information is necessary for a relative despite the decision of a patient not to give the information to that to this person, that they can give the information which is relevant to his or her.
To that third person.
Who are the rights holders so that the law is specifically saying who are those people?
Are just briefly to say the lies, also mentioning who are the persons who have the right to be present when the patient is treated.
So there are quite a lot of provisions to make life easier within the health institutions.
How the doctors can treat and reveal the personals.
The personal data of the patients to conclude there is one important article article in the Patients Act as also called Self Declaration.
When?
Medical institution finds out that the data of the patients was not treated according to the law.
They have to inform the Information Commissioner and the representative of patients rights, and then we have to perform an inspection to see what went wrong in the health institution.
And I have to say I've been dealing with personal data protection in my country for the last four years, and especially in the Medical Center.
We not medical system.
We now work hand in hand because we know and we are aware that we have to work.
Hand in hand because our goal is the same.
The protection of the patients data that data set.
City of the patients data.
So this is shortly from me.
I hope I was not too fast and too long.
Thank you for the attention Anne.
I'm of course here to answer your questions as well.
